text:
LARRY SUSSKIND: We hope you
will join our four-module dinner

series that we have produced
in conjunction with MIT

OpenCourseWare, with
graduate students in the MIT

Department of Urban
Studies and Planning,

who are eager to
explore the concept

of facilitative leadership
in the public sector.

We believe that leadership
in the public sector

requires special capabilities
and a certain mental attitude,

and we explore and discuss
lots of different versions

of those elements over the
four modules in the series.

This has particularly
been organized

for graduate students in the
Department of Urban Studies

and Planning because they
want to know about leadership

in the public sector, and there
are very few courses at MIT,

in any field, that talk about
leadership in the public sector.

We think it requires special
skills and microskills.

So we've organized four
dinner conversations.

And you'll get to
look over our shoulder

as I present some key
concepts and raise

some fundamental questions
in the first module.

And the goal of
that first module

is to get students
to think in terms

of their own personal
theories of practice.

The second module will look
at applying those concepts

in several
hypothetical situations

in the kinds of
public sector settings

that the participating
students who you will meet

will be working in
when they graduate.

The third module includes what
we call a role-play simulation,

in which students
attempt to interact

with several people with regard
to the ways in which development

should happen in
a particular city.

And in the context
and the conflict

that they're
participating in, they

have to use a set of
microskills, or at least try to.

And we'll talk about
the microskills

that are central to
facilitative leadership.

And finally, the
fourth module really

asks each of the 30
student participants

to make a personal
assessment of where

they think they stand
relative to what

it takes to be an effective,
facilitative leader.

You're welcome to watch one
or all four of the modules,

and I would be delighted to hear
from anyone who's watched them.

I would love to get a
conversation going globally

on facilitative leadership
in the public sector.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
